section.title: Horizontal Stretches and Compressions
section.p: In the previous section we discussed the result of multiplying the output of the function by a constant value. However, what happens when we multiply the input of the function? To explore this idea, we look at the graphs of f(x)=(x-1)^2 \text{, } ~f(2x)=(2x-1)^2\ \text{ ,and } ~f(\dfrac{1}{2}x)=(\dfrac{1}{2}x-1)^2 and discuss how they are related.

As we can see above, compared to the graph of f(x), the graph of f(2x) is compressed horizontally by a factor of 2 . Effectively, if we are given a point (x,y) on the graph of f(x) then (\dfrac{1}{2}x,y) is a point on the graph of f(2x).
Looking at the table above we can verify this for a few points. For example, the point (2,1) is on the graph of f(x). Then (\dfrac{1}{2}(2),1)=(1,1) is a point on the graph f(2x).

The graph of f(\dfrac{1}{2}x) is stretched horizontally by a factor of 2 compared to the graph of f(x) . Further, if (x,y) is a point on the graph of f(x), then (2x,y) is a point on the graph of f(\dfrac{1}{2}(x)).

We can see this playing out in our example above. Notice that (2,1) is a point on f(x), and (2(2),1)=(4,1) is a point on the graph of f(\dfrac{1}{2}x) as shown in the table and graph above. In general we have:

assemblage.title: Horizontal Stretches, Compressions, and Reflections
assemblage.p:
Compared with the graph of y = f (x), the graph of y = f (a\cdot x), where a \ne 0, is
compressed horizontally by a factor of \abs{a} if \abs{a}\gt 1,
stretched horizontally by a factor of \abs{\dfrac{1}{a}} if 0\lt\abs{a}\lt 1, and
reflected about the y-axis (and stretched or compressed) if a\lt 0.

section.p: As you may have notice by now through our examples, a horizontal stretch or compression will never change the y intercepts. This is a good way to tell if such a transformation has occurred.

sidebyside.p: The graph of f(x) is shown along with either a horizontal stretch of compression of f(x) . Decide if g(x) is a stretch or a compression, and give a formula for g(x) in terms of f(x).

solution.p: First, notice that the y-intercept stays fixed while the x-intercepts shift closer to the y-axis. This tells us that g(x) is a horizontal compression. The x -intercepts of f(x) are x=-1,1,2 while the x-intercepts of g(x) are x=-.5,.5,1.

So, the x-intercepts of g(x) can be achieved by taking the intercepts of f(x) and divide each by 2. This tells us that g(x) is a horizontal compression by a factor of 2 . Hence, we may write g(x)=f(2x).
